claim: High blood pressure increases the risk of heart disease and stroke, and it often has no warning signs.
Lifestyle changes such as a healthy diet, regular exercise, reducing salt intake, and avoiding tobacco use can help lower blood pressure.
Prescription blood pressure medications are safe and effective when taken as directed by a healthcare professional.
It is not safe to stop taking prescribed blood pressure medication without consulting a doctor.
Drinking herbal teas or meditating may help reduce stress, but they should not replace medical treatment for high blood pressure.
Exercise and a low-sodium diet both play important roles in managing high blood pressure.
The DASH diet is an evidence-based approach to reducing blood pressure.
Some people may require medication even with healthy lifestyle changes to manage their blood pressure.
Untreated high blood pressure can lead to serious complications such as kidney damage, heart failure, and vision loss.
Regular blood pressure monitoring is essential for early detection and management of hypertension.
